readings: On Reform (Sources of Korean Tradition, Ch. 22, pp. 70-116)

readingAnalyses.title: Reform Proposals (SKT Chapter 22)
readingAnalyses.author: Yu Hyŏngwŏn, Yi Ik, Chŏng Yagyong, Kim Yuk, Pak Chega
readingAnalyses.summary: Primary source excerpts from major Sirhak ('Practical Learning') scholars proposing reforms to land distribution, currency, and technology. Yu Hyŏngwŏn advocated radical redistribution based on the ancient well-field model; Yi Ik proposed pragmatic limits on landholding; Pak Chega argued Korea must learn from 'barbarian' Qing China to overcome technological backwardness.

keyQuotes.quote: Land is the foundation of everything under heaven. If that foundation is firmly established and in order, then everything else resting on that firm foundation will also be in perfect order.
The rich have vast lands that extend beyond the ridges in the fields, but the poor do not have enough land to stand an awl on; therefore the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.
A hundred would be overjoyed, but one would not be, and if the power of that one man would be enough to gag the mouths of the other hundred, how would one be able to carry it out?

Those who are idle and yet eat their fill are the great parasites of the country. That those who are idle and yet eat their fill increase every day is because the yangban get more prosperous every day.

If we now want to throw out the barbarians, we must first know what kind of people the barbarians are. If we want to revere China, there is no greater reverence than to put the Chinese ways into practice.

thematicExamples: Yu Hyŏngwŏn's 100-myo land allocation: every farmer receives standardized grants, with additional allotments for scholars based on rank
Pak Chega's devastating comparison: one Chinese winnowing fan lets one man process ten thousand sŏk of rice; Korean winnowing takes multiple workers one day for ten measures
Yi Ik's realist assessment: reform would benefit a hundred but harm one, and that one person's power 'gags the mouths' of the hundred
The Ch'oe clan holding lands yielding 10,000 bags of grain - taking the livelihoods of 3,990 people to enrich one family
realLifeConnections: Yi Ik's insight that 'the power of one man gags the mouths of the hundred' captures how entrenched interests block reforms that would benefit the majority - applicable to modern policy gridlock
Pak Chega's argument for learning from 'barbarians' parallels debates about technology transfer from geopolitical rivals
Land concentration parallels modern wealth inequality debates about the 1% vs 99%

readingAnalyses.title: Joseon Korea 1392-1800 (Ebrey Ch. 15)
readingAnalyses.author: Patricia Ebrey & Anne Walthall
readingAnalyses.summary: Provides essential political, economic, and cultural context for the reform debates. Covers factional strife culminating in Crown Prince Sado's tragic death (1762), economic changes including slavery's decline and commercialization, and cultural developments like Northern Learning and vernacular literature.

keyQuotes.quote: King Yeongjo decided to lock the prince in a small rice chest in the palace courtyard and left him to starve to death, which he did eight days later.
Between 1750 and 1790, there was a sharp reduction in the slave population from about 30 percent to less than 10 percent of the population.
The Northern Learning scholars urged that Korea learn from the Qing Dynasty to improve the economy and the material aspects of life.

thematicExamples: Crown Prince Sado's mental illness and murder by his father illustrates the suffocating pressure of Confucian court politics
Factions named for compass directions (Westerners, Easterners, Southerners, Northerners) plus Patriarchs and Disciples fought bitter purges
Currency returned to circulation in 1654 after Kim Yuk persuaded the king to accept cash for taxes
Chunhyang story: romantic tale of yangban son and courtesan's daughter that 'affirms the superiority of love over stifling convention'
Hong Daeyong rejected the idea that China was the center of the earth and criticized yangban disdain for manual labor
realLifeConnections: Crown Prince Sado's story inspired the acclaimed Korean film 'The Throne' (2015) - useful classroom connection
The decline of slavery shows that major social change was possible even without explicit reform legislation
Northern Learning's pragmatic embrace of 'enemy' knowledge parallels modern debates about learning from China

overallSynthesis:
The reform proposals must be read against the broader context Ebrey provides: late Joseon was a society in flux. Politically, bitter factional strife between Westerners, Southerners, Patriarchs, and Disciples produced purges and executions - culminating in the tragedy of Crown Prince Sado, starved to death by his own father King Yeongjo in 1762. Economically, significant changes were underway: slavery declined from 30% to under 10% of the population, currency returned to circulation after 1654, and commercialization expanded through fifth-day markets. Culturally, a new openness emerged - the Northern Learning (Pukhak) movement urged Korea to learn from Qing China despite viewing Manchus as 'barbarians,' while vernacular literature flourished in sijo poetry, novels like Chunhyang, and pansori oral traditions.

Against this backdrop, the Sirhak reformers diagnosed three interconnected crises: concentrated land ownership impoverishing peasants, inadequate monetary systems hampering commerce, and technological backwardness compared to China. The tragedy is that none of their proposals was implemented - reformers had to propose confiscating property from the very yangban class they belonged to. Korea entered the nineteenth century with the same structural problems, only to face Western and Japanese imperialism with an unreformed economy and society.

keywords.relevance: The intellectual movement uniting all the reform proposals; Korea's internal critique of its own society

keywords.relevance: Classical model reformers invoked for legitimacy; shows how they looked backward to justify moving forward

keywords.relevance: Most radical position - willing to learn from 'enemies' for practical benefits

keywords.definition: Hereditary aristocratic class of scholars/officials dominating Joseon society
keywords.relevance: Both the authors of reform proposals AND the main obstacle to implementation

keywords.definition: Bitter political divisions (Westerners, Easterners, Southerners, Northerners, Patriarchs, Disciples) that produced purges and executions
keywords.relevance: Political context that made coordinated reform impossible

keyQuestions.question: Yi Ik says even if reform would benefit a hundred people, the one person it would harm has 'power enough to gag the mouths of the hundred.' What does this tell us about ideas vs. power?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Reformers were members of the very class whose interests their proposals threatened. Ideas alone don't change society - you need political power. This is why none of these proposals was implemented until external pressure in the late 19th century.

keyQuestions.question: Pak Chega argues Korea should learn from Qing China even though the Manchus are 'barbarians.' Is this hypocrisy or pragmatism?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: He separates technology from cultural identity. Practical benefits outweigh cultural pride. Modern parallel: China adopting market capitalism while maintaining Communist Party rule. Can you separate useful knowledge from its source?

keyQuestions.question: How does the tragedy of Crown Prince Sado illuminate the political system these reformers were trying to change?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Sado's mental illness and murder by his father shows the suffocating pressure of Confucian court politics. Factionalism wasn't just abstract - it destroyed families. The same system that produced great scholarship also produced cruelty.

keyQuestions.question: Slavery declined from 30% to under 10% without any reform legislation. What does this tell us about how social change happens?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Economic forces (commercialization, runaway slaves, hired labor) achieved what reformers couldn't legislate. Sometimes change comes from below, not from elite proposals. But the yangban land system remained intact.

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 6 covered Qing's encounter with the West (Qianlong's letter to George III). Now we see Korean thinkers debating whether to learn from that same Qing China - a question of cultural pride vs. practical necessity. The Manchus were 'barbarians' but had conquered China and developed advanced technology.
connections.toNext: Plate 8 examines Tokugawa Japan's consolidation. Compare: Tokugawa established strict hierarchy to prevent change; Joseon reformers actively debated restructuring but couldn't implement. Different approaches to stability vs. reform - both would be disrupted by Western pressure in the 19th century.
connections.broaderThemes: These readings challenge the 'stagnant Asia' narrative. Korean intellectuals engaged in sophisticated debates about economics, technology, and social structure - not because Westerners told them to, but because their own society was in crisis. The pattern of recognizing problems but failing to implement solutions due to entrenched interests is universal.

nextPreview.preview: After a century of civil war, Tokugawa Ieyasu unified Japan and established a system designed to prevent future conflict through strict social hierarchy. How does Japan's 'freezing' of society compare to Korea's active but frustrated reform debates?

teachingNotes: TWO READINGS: Balance SKT primary sources with Ebrey's political/cultural context
Yi Ik's line about 'one person's power gagging the mouths of the hundred' is the most memorable quote - use it!
Pak Chega's comparison of Chinese vs Korean tools (winnowing fans, looms) is vivid and accessible
Crown Prince Sado story is dramatic - consider showing clip from 'The Throne' (2015)
Connect to Frank's ReORIENT: these are internal reform debates, not responses to Western pressure
Ask students: 'What reforms do we know are needed today but seem politically impossible?' (climate, inequality)
The yangban-as-parasites theme resonates with students - 'idle and yet eat their fill'
Map shows proposed maritime trade routes that reformers advocated

enrichment.title: Kisaeng Sijo: Women's Voices in Chosŏn Poetry
enrichment.introduction: The kisaeng (기생) were professional female entertainers trained in poetry, music, and dance. Their sijo poems offer a rare non-elite female perspective on love and loss in Chosŏn society. These poems circulated orally before being compiled into anthologies in the 18th-19th centuries—the same period that saw pansori and vernacular literature flourish.
enrichment.connectionToReadings: Like Chunhyang (mentioned in Ebrey), kisaeng sijo explore love across social boundaries. The kisaeng were 'destined forever to fall in love and never able to retain a lover.' Their emotional directness parallels the social critique found in pansori traditions.

poets.name: Hongnang
poets.bio: Kisaeng from Kyŏngsŏng in the far northeast. Met the poet Ch'oe Kyŏngch'ang when he traveled there on government business. When they parted as he returned to Seoul, she attached this sijo to a willow branch—following the Chinese custom of giving willow at farewells.

poems.title: Wild Willow Branch
poems.text:
I chose a wild willow branch and plucked it to send it to you.
I want you to plant it by the window where you sleep.
When new leaves open in the night rains, think it is I that have come to you.
poems.note: The poem transforms parting into continued presence through the living willow.

poets.name: Hwang Jini
poets.bio: The most famous kisaeng poet. Only six sijo survive, but her legendary beauty, wit, and defiance of convention made her an icon. Her poems use elaborate wordplay and double meanings.

poems.title: Long Winter Night
poems.text:
Oh that I might capture the essence of this deep midwinter night
And fold it softly into the waft of a spring-moon quilt,
Then fondly uncoil it the night my beloved returns.
poems.note: Written about the winter solstice (dongji). Compares long winter nights waiting for a lover with short spring nights spent together.

poems.title: I Cut in Two
poems.text:
I cut in two
A long November night, and
Place half under the coverlet,
Sweet-scented as a spring breeze.
And when he comes, I shall take it out,
Unroll it inch by inch, to stretch the night.
poems.note: Same theme as 'Long Winter Night'—the impossible wish to store time for later use with a lover.

poems.title: Blue Mountains Speak of My Desire
poems.text:
Blue mountains speak of my desire,
Green waters reflect my Lover's love:
The mountains unchanging,
The waters flowing by.
Sometimes it seems the waters cannot forget me,
They part in tears, regretting, running away.
poems.note: Mountains (unchanging) and water (flowing) represent the constancy of desire versus the transience of love.

discussionQuestions.question: How do these kisaeng poems compare to the elite male reformers we read about? What voices are missing from the reform debates?
discussionQuestions.talkingPoints: The reformers were yangban men proposing to redistribute yangban land. Kisaeng occupied the lowest social position—their daughters became kisaeng, their sons slaves. Yet they produced poetry admired by the very class that exploited them.

discussionQuestions.question: What does it mean that kisaeng poetry survived 'only against the odds'—passed orally before male scholars compiled anthologies?
discussionQuestions.talkingPoints: Women's literary production was systematically undervalued. The survival of these poems required male appreciation and preservation. How does this shape what we can know about women's experiences?
